A word of explanation to the person answering this questionnaire.

It is difficult to prepare a general questionnaire on pioneer life because no individual who has lived in Western Canada for more than one generation will have exactly the same experiences; others may prove impossible for you to answer, so don't worry about leaving blank spaces. Use extra sheets of paper if there is not sufficient space to answer the questions. Don't hesitate to give details, or describe particularly events, if they help to answer the questions.

This questionnaire is intended for persons who lived in Western Canada before 1914, and may be answered by anyone who has personal experience of the pioneer years whether born in this province or not.

If more than one member of the family can answer the questions, they should fill out separate sheets or apply for a separate questionnaire.

Other Questionnaires

Saskatchewan Archives questionnaires which have been prepared or projected are listed below. Please mark the ones you would be willing to answer.

- All questionnaires
- Pioneer diet
- Pioneer schools
- Pioneer churches
- Pioneer recreation and social life
- Pioneer farming experiences
- Folklore in Saskatchewan
- Pioneer health and housing

Preservation of Questionnaires

All questionnaires will be preserved in the Office of the Saskatchewan Archives at the University of Saskatchewan as part of the permanent record of our province. Please send your completed questionnaire to:

Saskatchewan Archives Office,
University of Saskatchewan,
Saskatoon, Saskatchewan.
1. Your full name: Sr. Marie Fabian de Sion (Sr. Marie Fabian de)

2. Your address: 800 Sion

3. Date: July 26, 1955

4. Where were you born? (Give name of place and country): Rockcliffe, Ont.

5. What was your father's name and occupation?: Martin O'Connor

6. When did you come to Saskatchewan? (Give month and year): August 24, 1904.

7. Mention any other places where you lived before coming to Saskatchewan, giving dates wherever possible:

   - Pembroke, Ontario; Cache Bay, Ont.

8. How old were you when you first came to Western Canada? (You do not need to answer this question if you would rather not or you may use "I was a child").

9. What were your reasons for coming West?

   - A teacher Miss O'Donnell (my schoolteacher) 25 miles from Pembroke asked me to come and I felt a little 9 months pregnant so I came to St. Joseph's Church in Rockcliffe Park in the spring of 1904. I traveled up a horse drawn sleigh and then walked to Pembroke. I worked for the B & P Railroad Co. on Prince Edward Rd.

10. How did you learn about the West? (Through other people? Reading about it?)

    - Miss De-tough (my who much be Jack Foster Lake)

    - Married the Education of the school, adopted by friends who were living in a glade on the farm, mother died, a Peter D. Smith (two children), called the boy James (no name) told the two children still, but Miss and the girl Roland. They moved to living still, but Miss had a family in a town she left China before the house was sold there or very soon after.
11. What did your friends and relatives think of your decision to come to Western Canada? They thought it was a good idea.

12. Did you travel by yourself or with a party (family, friends or other group)? I traveled alone.

13. What means of transportation did you use? By Canadian Pacific Railroad.

14. What incidents of the journey West do you remember? (People you met on the way, meetings with Indians, adventure on the journey, accidents or other excitement, etc.) Having my piano broken in Regina, I decided to finish school in Regina.

Passing through Ottawa, I met a young woman who asked me if she could stay at my house. She said yes.

Arriving in Calgary, I met a friend who invited me to his house.

15. Where did you first stay when you arrived in Saskatchewan? I stayed at the above, Regina.

16. Where did you settle or take up land? Regina, Alberta.

17. Mention any other places where you have lived since coming to Saskatchewan.

18. How did you earn a living before coming to Western Canada? How, after you arrived? I worked at home in Saskatoon.
25. When was the first car used in the community?

26. If you owned a car before 1914, when did you buy it? What make?

27. Where was your trading center? How far from your house?

28. Did you continue to trade there? (Indicate any changes due to new towns, appearance, better name of town, etc.)

29. How often did you shop in the early days?

30. When (if ever) did people in your district first start going to town regularly on Saturdays?

31. When (if ever) did you first begin to buy through the mail order catalogues? What kind of articles did you buy in this way? Indicate also what fraction of your total purchases were made by mail order and any changes in the proportion of purchases made by mail order since the pioneer period.

32. When did you first have a telephone and what company provided it?

33. When you came to Saskatchewan, the first time was it with the idea of staying permanently? Or did you make up your mind after trying it out? When did you make this decision?
34. Did any people move away from your district prior to 1914? What reasons did they have for moving?

35. Did many people move away during the 1930's? Did many return?

Would you or the person who came then either:
(1) be willing to lend them to the Provincial Archivist for copying?
(2) be willing to present them to the Archives Division of the Legislative Assembly?

36. If you or some member of your family have held public office, or have been active in any organizations, mention it here, giving dates wherever possible.

37. If you or any of your family or friends were "first" to have or do something in the district mention it here giving dates wherever possible. (Such as owning the first automobile, combine, organizing the first lodge, etc.)

38. How did the places in your community get their names? (School districts, Post Offices, villages, railway stations, creeks, hills, etc.). Try to give: (1) name and occupation of person suggesting place-name (2) origin and meaning of the name (3) date of its adoption (4) any changes in names since the first name was given, date and reason for change. Give facts of new name as above in (1), (2), (3).

Please give the names and addresses of other pioneers who could answer this questionnaire.

Do you have in your possession or do you know the whereabouts of diaries, old letters, old newspapers, old photographs, written recollections and reminiscences? (Describe.)
